October 22, 1900.

A DAY IN THE HAUNTS OF COLERIDGE AND WORDSWORTH.
The Doctor and I were bicycling in England,
in search of rest and of literary associations.
That day we found both. We had spent the
earlier hours of the August afternoon loitering
about the old abbey ruin of Glastonbury, which
lay dreaming in summer quiet so perfect that one
could easily believe this was indeed the"island
valley of Avilion,"
"Where falls not rain or hail, or any snow,
Nor ever wind blows loudly."
Thence we had wheeled over the high road that
skirts the field of Sedgemoor, and on through
the sleepy town of Bridgewater, so that it was
now past sundown when we coasted down a
gentle hill, under over-archin trees, and entered
Nether Stowev.

thereabout is soft and green, with groves and
lazy brooks, the ground falling now into little
valleys and then rising again int() easy sloping
hills, that a mile or so eastward run up to a
higher elevation,

No. 1.

_
to a flower show some miles away, and in the
absence of "The Missus," supper was an uncertain quantity ; but some one might be found to
get us a bit of baeon. Meantime, we started
out at once to find the object of our visit before
the long twilight should darken into night.
At the end of the street we found it—the last
cottage but one before the street runs out into
the open fields. A small square cottage, with a
neglected and lonesome look, its door opening
directly upon the roadside. But cheerless as it
looks now, and cheerless as it must have been to
outward looks a hundred years ago, there is
perhaps hardly a roof in England under which
there has been truer cheer or nobler thinking.
For this is the humble cottage of Toni Poole to
which came in the last days of 1797 Samuel
Taylor Coleridge, to -take up his abode, determined to live thriftily and to devote himself to
agriculture and literature. "We want but
three rooms," he wrote Poole;and by dismissing
his servant, practicing rigid economy, and
abstaining from animal food, he is confident that
he can sustain himself, his wife and child, on sixteen shillings a week. In the day-time he will
give himself, body and soul, to the garden ; in
the evenings, to literature. The agriculture, of
course, did not thrive; but the literature did.
It was in this little cottage that most of "The
Rime of the Ancient Mariner," and of the first
part of "Christabel" were written. It was sitting by the fireside in this tiny room that he
wrote those exquisite lines, Frost at Midnight,
while at his side his "cradled infant slumbered
peacefully." It was in the little parlor that
William and Dorothy Wordsworth paid their
first visit to him, and afterward talked many a
time far into the night. It was here, during this
visit of the Wordsworths, that Charles Lamb,
too, came to visit his earliest and best friend;
and in the room upstairs, Coleridge, detained at
home by illness while his friends were roaming
over the Quantock hills, wrote that touching
tribute to his friend, "The Lime Tree Bower My
Prison "—verses which he recalled with mourn

2

_

ful longings only a few weeks before he died.
This little cottage was the shrine of William
Hazlitt's pilgrimage, and here he passed three
happy weeks, sitting through the long summer
afternoons in the arbor in the back garden or
under the elm trees, "listening to the bees bumming around us while we quaffed our flip." It
was here that the fussy little Bristol bookseller
came to see the young poet, and in the arbor
struck the bargain for publishing that volume
which began the new poetry in England—Lyrcal Ballads.
A plain tablet has been affixed to the front wall
of the cottage, informing the passer-by that the
poet-philosoper once dwelt here; and the weary
looking little woman who now tenants it had
heard of the great Mr. Coleridge, and showed us
the room—the left-hand one,up the stair—where
"they say he used to sit and write." Sometimes
she had one or two lodgers, she said, mostly
city folk who wanted a bit of outing at little
cost; but very few people ever came to ask anything about Mr. Coleridge. She supposed he
was there a great while ago, and most people
had forgotten about it. The four rooms that
Coleridge and his family occupied can have
changed but little since he was here; but they
were frowsy and uninviting. The garden behind the cottage has been divided and most of it
sold; the arbor and the trees are gone. The
whole place had a rueful look, and it was bard
for us to people it with the forms that once held
converse there. As we left the garden in the
dusk and passed through the cottage again to
the street, the bare rooms reminded me most,not
of that glad summer of 1798, but of that next
winter, when Coleridge was in Germany, and
poor Sara Coleridge watched here through
mournful days and nights alone by the cradle of
her dying baby, and cried out, at last, that she
could stay in this place no longer.
Next morning we visited a fairer shrine. After
a night's sound sleep in the tidy attic of the
carter's house and an excellent breakfast which
"the Missus" insisted on serving with her own
hands, we rode over to Alfoxden House, where
Wordsworth lived in that annus mirabllis,179798. The poets used to say it was a walk of only
three miles; our prosaic cyclometers made it

nearly five. But the last mile and a-half of the
way lay through that park and wood which is
consecrated by such frequent poetic mention.
This is the walk that young Hazlitt took
"through echoing grove, by fairy stream and
waterfall, glimmering in the summer moonlight," while all the while the orphic voice of
Coleridge by his side sounded high
"Of Providence, foreknowledge, will and fate."

It was along this path that Coleridge and
Wordsworth walked a hundred times together;
it was in a glade by the brook here that Coleridge exclaimed one morning, "This is a place to
reconcile one to all the jarrings and conflicts of
the world "; it was in these trees that the nightingales sang all that spring, and sing forever in
Coleridge's verse. In this park lived the old
huntsman, Simon Lee, and it was here that
wordsworth wrote the Night Piece, and the
Lines in Early Spring, and Expostulation and
Reply. The walk can have changed little since
then, for the forest is old and has been carefully
preserved; the stream still skips and sings, and
"'Twill murmur on a thousand years,
And flow as now it flows."

The house, too, though slightly enlarged, can
hardly have been altered much since Wordsworth
and Dorothywere here; Dorothy's description ofit
in her delightful journal might have been written
yesterday. It stands solid,almost stately,fronting the south,at thefoot ofa smooth hill that rises
almost from the very door, still "topped with
fern and sprinkled with trees," as when Dorothy looked out upon it. To the west a growth
of young wood has shut out the view of the sea
she says she had; but otherwise we see to-day
what Dorothy saw.
We were fortunate in the time of our visit, as
the house was occupied only by a care-taker,and
a note to him from our host of the Stowey Inn
gained us permission to look about it as we
chose. Here was the chamber in which Hazlitt
slept on the night of his stay at Alfoxden,and in
the morning from his window that looked upon
the hill, "heard the loud stag speak." Here in
Dorothy's sitting-room a climbing rose had
thrust a spray of blossoms in at the open window where she used to sit. But after all it was

THE NEWS-LETTER,
most pleasant to lie upon the turf outside, under
the same great elms that shadowed the poet in
their youth a century ago, repeat his verses,and
read once more Dorothy's charming Journal.
We lingered here till noon, letting the scene photograph itself in our memory, and then we rode
on, over the Quantocks, past Kilve church—
where "there is no weather-cock "—to Porlock.
In this most picturesque of all English villages,
hidden in one of the bowery clefts that break the
high line of the Devon coast, we saw the very
"man from Porlock" that disturbed the vision
of Kubla Khan; we—but that is another story.
C. T. WINCHESTER,
Prof. of English in Wesleyan University.

STEPHEN PHILLIPS'"PAOLO AND
FRANCESCA."
One eve, upon the hills at Rimini
Aglow with garlands of the breathing South,
I climbed a wall, half by a convent hid,
Across to some deep-verdured still demesne
Where the liandri bowed their pink, pure lips.
To whisper to the dusty pilgrim, faint
From weary plodding up the mountain side,
An invitation to a languorous rest
And far-eyed dream of the fair vales of life
Where once he roamed and would fare on refreshed
In scenes enframed in beauty as of Tuscan hills.
Twas there I plucked a flower sweet grown
By ministrations of another's hand
And as its beauty seemed to magnify
When plucked unwilling from another's garth
I grew philosopher and calmly read
Anew the still, sad story of the loves
Of young Francesca, and brave Paolo,
Who clad yet in the dented armour of the fray
With tender doubt and manly zeal misplaced,
Bowed to a sweet, compelling fate, when worn
With all the tiresome traffic of the road,
And in his brother's garden plucked the fruit
Forbidden since the memory of man.

Then the warm fragrance of the sunset hour,
And Night's pale vintage of her evening dew
Distilling attar from the stolen bloom,
mused on Omar and The Table Round—
Old tales of little immoralities
Won in the mirage of a moment's glow—
And laughed at Fate and loved and understood.
But in my eager hand the fragrant flower
Had slowy pined and paled and drooped and (led,
The evanescent beauty ()I a dream.

Owing to the fact that to many the Tuesday
afternoon hour for prayer meeting has seemed
very inconvenient, it has been decided to hold
another meeting Sunday afternoon at 5 o'clock.
These meetings are to be made attractive by
good music and strong leaders, and a large
attendance is earnestly desired. It is hoped that
the undergraduates in particular will take up
the effort, and make it successful.
It should be particularly noted that the prayer
meetings Tuesday, at 5 P. M., are not to be discontinued. The new Sunday services are intended only for those who find the hour more
convenient. Also the daily morning prayer
meeting, lasting from 8.45 to 8.55, will be continued during this year.
The Y. M. C. A. offers a hearty invitation to
all students to join in all these ser vices.

The first fall issue of the NEWS-LETTER has
from prehistoric times contained editorials on
two subjects which cannot be too much harped,
viz: Support of the NEWS-LETTER by the
student body and the importance of an effective
foot-ball scrub. I decided at first to clip and
insert the many and interesting articles written
by earlier editors upon these two absorbing
topics. As however the amount of such matter
would probably fill several folio volumes, I shall
endeavor to give merely the barest gist of the
thing.
The NEws-LETTHR should be subscribed and
contributed to by the student body for the following cogent reasons: It is a college institution of undoubted worth and long standing,
countenanced by the fitculty and the dean. It
is the only official organ through which the
students may vent their opinions, cry their
wrongs, glory in their victories, and efferverse
in verse by the aid of its masterly and powerful
columns, they can do all these things in plain
print and receive that respectful attention which
can be assured only by the weight (the moral
weight) of a free, conservative, and carefully
edited paper, which has during years of right
living gained the respect and confidence of successive generations of subscribers. There, now.
The importance of an effective foot-ball scrub
is too obvious to be dwelt upon at length. The
Scrub gives the Varsity Eleven practice which

The band of Hopkins "rooters" that assembled at Union Park to witness the J. H. U.—Delaware College game was discouragingly small.
Possibly the majority of the student body imagined that the rain would prevent the game from
taking place, but as guarantees are posted
beforehand our football schedule this fall will be
unaffected by the elements. First—As patriotic
supporters of the Black and Blue, our students
should take some interest in our athletic sports.
Second—Our athletes who give a certain amount
of their time and labor in order to win fresh
laurels for the University, deserve the support
and encouragement of their comrades. Third—
Advertising, railroad transportation and ITnion
Park are not on the free list.
May college spirit pervade the air, and in the
future may a larger attendance cheer our team
to victory

"COLLEGE SPIRITS."
We are very glad to print a letter we have
received signed "A Preshman," for we can
always find space for contributions so full of fascinating interest as the following. Our correspondent is all right ; THE NEws-LETTER ought
to be improved. We have two or three ideas
along that line ourselves. His motto, however,
is now nailed to the top of oureditorial desk and
is a source of considerable inspiration to us.
Juniors and Seniors will read this letter with a
good deal of satisfaction. We hope they will
fall in with its"spirits." There is also a modest
suggestion to the faculty.
Dear Mr. Editor: I have not been at Hopkins
very long, but I am very full of Hopkins spirits,
and I want to write something for THE NEWSLETTER right off. I think everybody ought to
write for THE NEWS LETTER and help to make

toalltet:

THE NEWS-LETTER.
it better. I read once that "Improvement is
the order of the age." I am a firm believer in
college spirits. We ought to have more at
Hopkins.
Now, to make a practical suggestion, I think
if the junior class, since we do not have any
more hazing, if they would give some kind of a
reception or "feed" to the freshmen and tell
them all about things and how to yell and
what to do at the games it would be a good
thing. The seniors might also do this. And
then the professors ought to buy tickets for the
games.
Another good thing for college spirits is to
wear a Hopkins pin. I have one I wear every
day and it attracts a great deal of attention.
You see the better your college is known the
more men come to it and you can have bigger
teams. In this way we could get into the class
with Yale and Harvard and other big schools.
I am a firm believer in pins.
Lastly I think every fellow ought to work
hard at his studies and to raise the standard of
his institution. This has more to do with college spirits than you would at first think for it
would bring a better class of men to your college and there would be more spirits. I do not
think it is good to drink or smoke cigarettes
while you are studying, though I once knew a
fellow who got a scholarship and drank a good
deal of beer. (It was at another college). It is
also very bad for the teams,for you cannot play
foot-ball and drink beer at the same time. Every
physical director ought to make very strict
rules about this and set his men a good example,
though I suppose nothing of this kind is called
for in our university with its high standing.
But humanum est errare.
A FRESHMAN.
P. S.—If you do not think this is fit to print
please put it in my box, for I like to keep the
things I write. Perhaps I could use it for an
essay in Dr. Green's course. Why don't you
print stories in THE NEws LETTER ? I write
them occasionally.

MUSICAL CLUBS.
The musical clubs,judging from the number of
applicants who have presented themselves for
trial, have a successful year before them. There
were many serious predictions for the future of
the clubs At the close of last year, for a large
number of the members would not be here this
year to aid in making things joyful or otherwise.
But as most other storm clouds, these rumors
passed off after a little noise as quietly as they
had come and now everything points to a most
promising year with as good if not better clubs
than formerly. Of course there have been serious
losses both in men and leaders, but even now
with the loss of I. A.Thorson, leader of the Mandolin Club, and Girvin Peters, leader of the Glee
Club, the musical clubs are not as badly off as
they were at the beginning of last year. For
then there was no one who would undertake to
lead the Banjo Club. Peters was not sure
whether he would have time for the Glee Club,
and Vogeler was compelled to resign his leadership of the Mandolin Club immediately after it
had gotten into good shape. But now all three
clubs have leaders and every member takes a
lively interest in the welfare of the clubs. One
other thing that points to success is that Manager Bird has made the very best contract that
the clubs have ever made with Mr. Fisher, by
which he will give the Glee Club a larger proportion of his time than usual.
The men who have been received as candidates
for the clubs up to date include: Wolf, Nelson,
Hendry, Humrichouse, Corner, Hill, E. C.,
Tootle, Morgan, Pagon, Bryan, Campla,
Bacon, Briscoe, Marshall, Dapprich, Mason,
Lanier, Hazlehurst, Richardson, Gaines,Vogeler.

lead the Glee Club as was formerly planned. J.
H. Eyster., however, has consented to fill the

THE NEWS-LETTER.
TRACK TEAM.

The prospects for a crack-a-jack track team to
represent Hopkinson the field this year are much
better than ever before, and Director Mackdermott is greatly pleased with the present outlook.
Already training has been begun by a few of the
men, but in the course of the next week or two
Mr. Mackdermott will institute a thorough
course of preliminary training for all candidates
for the team.
Watson and Karsted, the Medical School men
on last year's team, are in town and no effort
Nv i 1 I be spared to have them again become mem;
hers of our team. Woodruff, who has entered
the business world, will not return to the University this year and will be much missed in the
long distances. Atkinson, the Marston's boy,
who did so well last year in the Interscholastic
games at Electric Park, is in the University and
will be a great addition to the sprinters. Hayden, a new graduate student, and Terry, from
Vanderbilt University, will be fast men for the
quarter and half, and Thatcher,a new man from
Swarthmore, will endeavor to fill the gap caused
by Woodruff's absence, in the mile run. Nearly
all of last year's track and field men have
returned to their studies and will work harder
than ever this year for the success of the team.
Mr. Mackdermott says that he will enter this
year's team in the games at the Pan-American
Exposition, at Buffalo, and at the Inter-Collegiate games, to he held in New York next spring,
and hopes to bring back several trophies for the
common room.
*"'Or slIr

IMPROVEMENTS TO THE GYM.
Among the first things noticed by those returning here are the improvements which have been
made to the Gymnasium and Cage. The whole
building has been fitted with electric lights,
which should do away with two of the most
objectionable features of last year. The daily
escape of gas in the gymnasium proper was
exceedingly annoying both to the instructors
and students, who were compelled to forego the
pleasure of breathing exercises for fear of being
asphixiated. With electric lights there is no

longer any danger. Gas constantly lit in the
locker room caused an unnecessary closeness of
the atmosphere; even in cold weather the lockerroom air was not pure. In addition to the electric lights, a large new closet for foot-ball suits
and lacrosse sticks has been placed in the wrestling room, and a new entrance to the cage has
been made. The cage itself has been plowed,and
the excess of brick and rocks removed. The gym.
has been repainted and varnished for the especial use of the Freshmen. The gallery and swimming pool are promised, and we have no doubt
that they will sooner or later be forthcoming.
Thanks for the improvement, Mr. Maekdermott.

INTERCOLLEGIATE MEEETING.
The Maryland Intercollegiate Association met
in the University Gymnasium on Saturday. Delegates were present from Johns Hopkins, St.
John's and Western Maryland. Officers were
elected as follows: President, James A. Fechtig
of St. John's; Vice-President, Albert M. Reese
of Johns Hopkins; Secretary, William M. Mackdermott of Johns Hopkins; Treasurer, William
Black of Western Maryland.
The Association manifested its hearty concurrence in the spirit of the proposed new rules
of the National Intercollegiate body tending
toward purer athletics. A resolution was
passed directing that the managers submit to
each other and to the secretary ten days before
the opening game each season duplicate lists of
their players so that their status may be definitely ascertained. Permission was given Western
Maryland to play a game scheduled with the
Maryland Agricultural College in ignorance of
the prohibition lately imposed.
The next meeting will be held the first Saturday in December.

At the Paris Exposition, Hopkins secured two
Grand Prizes, the highest possible award, and a
gold medal for the exhibits in the department of
educational publications. This was the highest
award given to an American exhibition in this
department.

THE BOOK CORNER.
The speculations of the editors of the N. Y.
Times Saturday Review as to who wrote "Elizabeth and her German Garden," resembled the
Pet guessing contests of another N. Y. paper
more famous but not so harmless as is our friend,
the Review. The Review successively placed
the author of "Elizabeth" in the persons
of the Princess Henry of Pless, and the Countess von Arnim. In spite of the Review's absolute conviction on the subject, the author
turned out to be a "plain and simple" American, a Mrs. Cabbel, of Richmond, who has been
writing those rather piquant columns in our
Baltimore Sun signed Carisabel.

If Mrs. Wharton's "The Valley of Decision"
approaches her beautiful and carefully finished
short story in the August Scribner entitled "The
Duchess at Prayer," it must be well worth reading. Both novel and short story portray court
and country life in Northern Italy in the
eighteenth century. The illustrations of the
latter by our old friend, Maxfield Parrish, add
greatly to its charm.

When Sir Philip Sidney was dying at Zutphen
he was offered a cup of water. Seeing a soldier
nearby badly Wounded, he said,"No, give it to
him ; he needs it worse than I do." Such are
the terrible results of the use of alcoholic beverages. If he could not have beer he would
have nothing.

October 22, 1900.

A DAY IN THE HAUNTS OF COLERIDGE AND WORDSWORTH.
The Doctor and I were bicycling in England,
in search of rest and of literary associations.
That day we found both. We had spent the
earlier hours of the August afternoon loitering
about the old abbey ruin of Glastonbury, which
lay dreaming in summer quiet so perfect that one
could easily believe this was indeed the"island
valley of Avilion,"
"Where falls not rain or hail, or any snow,
Nor ever wind blows loudly."
Thence we had wheeled over the high road that
skirts the field of Sedgemoor, and on through
the sleepy town of Bridgewater, so that it was
now past sundown when we coasted down a
gentle hill, under over-archin trees, and entered
Nether Stowev.

lazy brooks, the ground falling now into little
valleys and then rising again int() easy sloping
hills, that a mile or so eastward run up to a
higher elevation,

No. 1.

_
to a flower show some miles away, and in the
absence of "The Missus," supper was an uncertain quantity ; but some one might be found to
get us a bit of baeon. Meantime, we started
out at once to find the object of our visit before
the long twilight should darken into night.
At the end of the street we found it—the last
cottage but one before the street runs out into
the open fields. A small square cottage, with a
neglected and lonesome look, its door opening
directly upon the roadside. But cheerless as it
looks now, and cheerless as it must have been to
outward looks a hundred years ago, there is
perhaps hardly a roof in England under which
there has been truer cheer or nobler thinking.
For this is the humble cottage of Toni Poole to
which came in the last days of 1797 Samuel
Taylor Coleridge, to -take up his abode, determined to live thriftily and to devote himself to
agriculture and literature. "We want but
three rooms," he wrote Poole;and by dismissing
his servant, practicing rigid economy, and
abstaining from animal food, he is confident that
he can sustain himself, his wife and child, on sixteen shillings a week. In the day-time he will
give himself, body and soul, to the garden ; in
the evenings, to literature. The agriculture, of
course, did not thrive; but the literature did.
It was in this little cottage that most of "The
Rime of the Ancient Mariner," and of the first
part of "Christabel" were written. It was sitting by the fireside in this tiny room that he
wrote those exquisite lines, Frost at Midnight,
while at his side his "cradled infant slumbered
peacefully." It was in the little parlor that
William and Dorothy Wordsworth paid their
first visit to him, and afterward talked many a
time far into the night. It was here, during this
visit of the Wordsworths, that Charles Lamb,
too, came to visit his earliest and best friend;
and in the room upstairs, Coleridge, detained at
home by illness while his friends were roaming
over the Quantock hills, wrote that touching
tribute to his friend, "The Lime Tree Bower My
Prison "—verses which he recalled with mourn

2

THE NEWS-LETTER.
_

ful longings only a few weeks before he died.
This little cottage was the shrine of William
Hazlitt's pilgrimage, and here he passed three
happy weeks, sitting through the long summer
afternoons in the arbor in the back garden or
under the elm trees, "listening to the bees bumming around us while we quaffed our flip." It
was here that the fussy little Bristol bookseller
came to see the young poet, and in the arbor
struck the bargain for publishing that volume
which began the new poetry in England—Lyrcal Ballads.
A plain tablet has been affixed to the front wall
of the cottage, informing the passer-by that the
poet-philosoper once dwelt here; and the weary
looking little woman who now tenants it had
heard of the great Mr. Coleridge, and showed us
the room—the left-hand one,up the stair—where
"they say he used to sit and write." Sometimes
she had one or two lodgers, she said, mostly
city folk who wanted a bit of outing at little
cost; but very few people ever came to ask anything about Mr. Coleridge. She supposed he
was there a great while ago, and most people
had forgotten about it. The four rooms that
Coleridge and his family occupied can have
changed but little since he was here; but they
were frowsy and uninviting. The garden behind the cottage has been divided and most of it
sold; the arbor and the trees are gone. The
whole place had a rueful look, and it was bard
for us to people it with the forms that once held
converse there. As we left the garden in the
dusk and passed through the cottage again to
the street, the bare rooms reminded me most,not
of that glad summer of 1798, but of that next
winter, when Coleridge was in Germany, and
poor Sara Coleridge watched here through
mournful days and nights alone by the cradle of
her dying baby, and cried out, at last, that she
could stay in this place no longer.
Next morning we visited a fairer shrine. After
a night's sound sleep in the tidy attic of the
carter's house and an excellent breakfast which
"the Missus" insisted on serving with her own
hands, we rode over to Alfoxden House, where
Wordsworth lived in that annus mirabllis,179798. The poets used to say it was a walk of only
three miles; our prosaic cyclometers made it

nearly five. But the last mile and a-half of the
way lay through that park and wood which is
consecrated by such frequent poetic mention.
This is the walk that young Hazlitt took
"through echoing grove, by fairy stream and
waterfall, glimmering in the summer moonlight," while all the while the orphic voice of
Coleridge by his side sounded high
"Of Providence, foreknowledge, will and fate."

It was along this path that Coleridge and
Wordsworth walked a hundred times together;
it was in a glade by the brook here that Coleridge exclaimed one morning, "This is a place to
reconcile one to all the jarrings and conflicts of
the world "; it was in these trees that the nightingales sang all that spring, and sing forever in
Coleridge's verse. In this park lived the old
huntsman, Simon Lee, and it was here that
wordsworth wrote the Night Piece, and the
Lines in Early Spring, and Expostulation and
Reply. The walk can have changed little since
then, for the forest is old and has been carefully
preserved; the stream still skips and sings, and
"'Twill murmur on a thousand years,
And flow as now it flows."

The house, too, though slightly enlarged, can
hardly have been altered much since Wordsworth
and Dorothywere here; Dorothy's description ofit
in her delightful journal might have been written
yesterday. It stands solid,almost stately,fronting the south,at thefoot ofa smooth hill that rises
almost from the very door, still "topped with
fern and sprinkled with trees," as when Dorothy looked out upon it. To the west a growth
of young wood has shut out the view of the sea
she says she had; but otherwise we see to-day
what Dorothy saw.
We were fortunate in the time of our visit, as
the house was occupied only by a care-taker,and
a note to him from our host of the Stowey Inn
gained us permission to look about it as we
chose. Here was the chamber in which Hazlitt
slept on the night of his stay at Alfoxden,and in
the morning from his window that looked upon
the hill, "heard the loud stag speak." Here in
Dorothy's sitting-room a climbing rose had
thrust a spray of blossoms in at the open window where she used to sit. But after all it was

THE NEWS-LETTER,
most pleasant to lie upon the turf outside, under
the same great elms that shadowed the poet in
their youth a century ago, repeat his verses,and
read once more Dorothy's charming Journal.
We lingered here till noon, letting the scene photograph itself in our memory, and then we rode
on, over the Quantocks, past Kilve church—
where "there is no weather-cock "—to Porlock.
In this most picturesque of all English villages,
hidden in one of the bowery clefts that break the
high line of the Devon coast, we saw the very
"man from Porlock" that disturbed the vision
of Kubla Khan; we—but that is another story.
C. T. WINCHESTER,
Prof. of English in Wesleyan University.

STEPHEN PHILLIPS'"PAOLO AND
FRANCESCA."
One eve, upon the hills at Rimini
Aglow with garlands of the breathing South,
I climbed a wall, half by a convent hid,
Across to some deep-verdured still demesne
Where the liandri bowed their pink, pure lips.
To whisper to the dusty pilgrim, faint
From weary plodding up the mountain side,
An invitation to a languorous rest
And far-eyed dream of the fair vales of life
Where once he roamed and would fare on refreshed
In scenes enframed in beauty as of Tuscan hills.
Twas there I plucked a flower sweet grown
By ministrations of another's hand
And as its beauty seemed to magnify
When plucked unwilling from another's garth
I grew philosopher and calmly read
Anew the still, sad story of the loves
Of young Francesca, and brave Paolo,
Who clad yet in the dented armour of the fray
With tender doubt and manly zeal misplaced,
Bowed to a sweet, compelling fate, when worn
With all the tiresome traffic of the road,
And in his brother's garden plucked the fruit
Forbidden since the memory of man.

Then the warm fragrance of the sunset hour,
And Night's pale vintage of her evening dew
Distilling attar from the stolen bloom,
mused on Omar and The Table Round—
Old tales of little immoralities
Won in the mirage of a moment's glow—
And laughed at Fate and loved and understood.
But in my eager hand the fragrant flower
Had slowy pined and paled and drooped and (led,
The evanescent beauty ()I a dream.

Owing to the fact that to many the Tuesday
afternoon hour for prayer meeting has seemed
very inconvenient, it has been decided to hold
another meeting Sunday afternoon at 5 o'clock.
These meetings are to be made attractive by
good music and strong leaders, and a large
attendance is earnestly desired. It is hoped that
the undergraduates in particular will take up
the effort, and make it successful.
It should be particularly noted that the prayer
meetings Tuesday, at 5 P. M., are not to be discontinued. The new Sunday services are intended only for those who find the hour more
convenient. Also the daily morning prayer
meeting, lasting from 8.45 to 8.55, will be continued during this year.
The Y. M. C. A. offers a hearty invitation to
all students to join in all these ser vices.

The first fall issue of the NEWS-LETTER has
from prehistoric times contained editorials on
two subjects which cannot be too much harped,
viz: Support of the NEWS-LETTER by the
student body and the importance of an effective
foot-ball scrub. I decided at first to clip and
insert the many and interesting articles written
by earlier editors upon these two absorbing
topics. As however the amount of such matter
would probably fill several folio volumes, I shall
endeavor to give merely the barest gist of the
thing.
The NEws-LETTHR should be subscribed and
contributed to by the student body for the following cogent reasons: It is a college institution of undoubted worth and long standing,
countenanced by the fitculty and the dean. It
is the only official organ through which the
students may vent their opinions, cry their
wrongs, glory in their victories, and efferverse
in verse by the aid of its masterly and powerful
columns, they can do all these things in plain
print and receive that respectful attention which
can be assured only by the weight (the moral
weight) of a free, conservative, and carefully
edited paper, which has during years of right
living gained the respect and confidence of successive generations of subscribers. There, now.
The importance of an effective foot-ball scrub
is too obvious to be dwelt upon at length. The

and encouragement of their comrades. Third—
Advertising, railroad transportation and ITnion
Park are not on the free list.
May college spirit pervade the air, and in the
future may a larger attendance cheer our team

"COLLEGE SPIRITS."
We are very glad to print a letter we have
received signed "A Preshman," for we can
always find space for contributions so full of fascinating interest as the following. Our correspondent is all right ; THE NEws-LETTER ought
to be improved. We have two or three ideas
along that line ourselves. His motto, however,
is now nailed to the top of oureditorial desk and
is a source of considerable inspiration to us.
Juniors and Seniors will read this letter with a
good deal of satisfaction. We hope they will
fall in with its"spirits." There is also a modest
suggestion to the faculty.
Dear Mr. Editor: I have not been at Hopkins
very long, but I am very full of Hopkins spirits,
and I want to write something for THE NEWSLETTER right off. I think everybody ought to
write for THE NEWS LETTER and help to make

toalltet:

THE NEWS-LETTER.
it better. I read once that "Improvement is
the order of the age." I am a firm believer in
college spirits. We ought to have more at
Hopkins.
Now, to make a practical suggestion, I think
if the junior class, since we do not have any
more hazing, if they would give some kind of a
reception or "feed" to the freshmen and tell
them all about things and how to yell and
what to do at the games it would be a good
thing. The seniors might also do this. And
then the professors ought to buy tickets for the
games.
Another good thing for college spirits is to
wear a Hopkins pin. I have one I wear every
day and it attracts a great deal of attention.
You see the better your college is known the
more men come to it and you can have bigger
teams. In this way we could get into the class
with Yale and Harvard and other big schools.
I am a firm believer in pins.
Lastly I think every fellow ought to work
hard at his studies and to raise the standard of
his institution. This has more to do with college spirits than you would at first think for it
would bring a better class of men to your college and there would be more spirits. I do not
think it is good to drink or smoke cigarettes
while you are studying, though I once knew a
fellow who got a scholarship and drank a good
deal of beer. (It was at another college). It is
also very bad for the teams,for you cannot play
foot-ball and drink beer at the same time. Every
physical director ought to make very strict
rules about this and set his men a good example,
though I suppose nothing of this kind is called
for in our university with its high standing.
But humanum est errare.
A FRESHMAN.
P. S.—If you do not think this is fit to print
please put it in my box, for I like to keep the
things I write. Perhaps I could use it for an
essay in Dr. Green's course. Why don't you
print stories in THE NEws LETTER ? I write
them occasionally.

MUSICAL CLUBS.
The musical clubs,judging from the number of
applicants who have presented themselves for
trial, have a successful year before them. There
were many serious predictions for the future of
the clubs At the close of last year, for a large
number of the members would not be here this
year to aid in making things joyful or otherwise.
But as most other storm clouds, these rumors
passed off after a little noise as quietly as they
had come and now everything points to a most
promising year with as good if not better clubs
than formerly. Of course there have been serious
losses both in men and leaders, but even now
with the loss of I. A.Thorson, leader of the Mandolin Club, and Girvin Peters, leader of the Glee
Club, the musical clubs are not as badly off as
they were at the beginning of last year. For
then there was no one who would undertake to
lead the Banjo Club. Peters was not sure
whether he would have time for the Glee Club,
and Vogeler was compelled to resign his leadership of the Mandolin Club immediately after it
had gotten into good shape. But now all three
clubs have leaders and every member takes a
lively interest in the welfare of the clubs. One
other thing that points to success is that Manager Bird has made the very best contract that
the clubs have ever made with Mr. Fisher, by
which he will give the Glee Club a larger proportion of his time than usual.
The men who have been received as candidates
for the clubs up to date include: Wolf, Nelson,
Hendry, Humrichouse, Corner, Hill, E. C.,
Tootle, Morgan, Pagon, Bryan, Campla,
Bacon, Briscoe, Marshall, Dapprich, Mason,
Lanier, Hazlehurst, Richardson, Gaines,Vogeler.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
TRACK TEAM.

The prospects for a crack-a-jack track team to
represent Hopkinson the field this year are much
better than ever before, and Director Mackdermott is greatly pleased with the present outlook.
Already training has been begun by a few of the
men, but in the course of the next week or two
Mr. Mackdermott will institute a thorough
course of preliminary training for all candidates
for the team.
Watson and Karsted, the Medical School men
on last year's team, are in town and no effort
Nv i 1 I be spared to have them again become mem;
hers of our team. Woodruff, who has entered
the business world, will not return to the University this year and will be much missed in the
long distances. Atkinson, the Marston's boy,
who did so well last year in the Interscholastic
games at Electric Park, is in the University and
will be a great addition to the sprinters. Hayden, a new graduate student, and Terry, from
Vanderbilt University, will be fast men for the
quarter and half, and Thatcher,a new man from
Swarthmore, will endeavor to fill the gap caused
by Woodruff's absence, in the mile run. Nearly
all of last year's track and field men have
returned to their studies and will work harder
than ever this year for the success of the team.
Mr. Mackdermott says that he will enter this
year's team in the games at the Pan-American
Exposition, at Buffalo, and at the Inter-Collegiate games, to he held in New York next spring,
and hopes to bring back several trophies for the
common room.

IMPROVEMENTS TO THE GYM.
Among the first things noticed by those returning here are the improvements which have been
made to the Gymnasium and Cage. The whole
building has been fitted with electric lights,
which should do away with two of the most
objectionable features of last year. The daily
escape of gas in the gymnasium proper was
exceedingly annoying both to the instructors
and students, who were compelled to forego the
pleasure of breathing exercises for fear of being
asphixiated. With electric lights there is no

longer any danger. Gas constantly lit in the
locker room caused an unnecessary closeness of
the atmosphere; even in cold weather the lockerroom air was not pure. In addition to the electric lights, a large new closet for foot-ball suits
and lacrosse sticks has been placed in the wrestling room, and a new entrance to the cage has
been made. The cage itself has been plowed,and
the excess of brick and rocks removed. The gym.
has been repainted and varnished for the especial use of the Freshmen. The gallery and swimming pool are promised, and we have no doubt
that they will sooner or later be forthcoming.
Thanks for the improvement, Mr. Maekdermott.

INTERCOLLEGIATE MEEETING.
The Maryland Intercollegiate Association met
in the University Gymnasium on Saturday. Delegates were present from Johns Hopkins, St.
John's and Western Maryland. Officers were
elected as follows: President, James A. Fechtig
of St. John's; Vice-President, Albert M. Reese
of Johns Hopkins; Secretary, William M. Mackdermott of Johns Hopkins; Treasurer, William
Black of Western Maryland.
The Association manifested its hearty concurrence in the spirit of the proposed new rules
of the National Intercollegiate body tending
toward purer athletics. A resolution was
passed directing that the managers submit to
each other and to the secretary ten days before
the opening game each season duplicate lists of
their players so that their status may be definitely ascertained. Permission was given Western
Maryland to play a game scheduled with the
Maryland Agricultural College in ignorance of
the prohibition lately imposed.
The next meeting will be held the first Saturday in December.

THE BOOK CORNER.
The speculations of the editors of the N. Y.
Times Saturday Review as to who wrote "Elizabeth and her German Garden," resembled the
Pet guessing contests of another N. Y. paper
more famous but not so harmless as is our friend,
the Review. The Review successively placed
the author of "Elizabeth" in the persons
of the Princess Henry of Pless, and the Countess von Arnim. In spite of the Review's absolute conviction on the subject, the author
turned out to be a "plain and simple" American, a Mrs. Cabbel, of Richmond, who has been
writing those rather piquant columns in our

If Mrs. Wharton's "The Valley of Decision"
approaches her beautiful and carefully finished
short story in the August Scribner entitled "The
Duchess at Prayer," it must be well worth reading. Both novel and short story portray court
and country life in Northern Italy in the
eighteenth century. The illustrations of the
latter by our old friend, Maxfield Parrish, add
greatly to its charm.

When Sir Philip Sidney was dying at Zutphen
he was offered a cup of water. Seeing a soldier
nearby badly Wounded, he said,"No, give it to
him ; he needs it worse than I do." Such are
the terrible results of the use of alcoholic beverages. If he could not have beer he would
have nothing.
